verses.text: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: Standard introductory formula for divine speech.

verses.text: Speak to the people of Israel and say to them, 'These are the appointed feasts of the Lord that you shall proclaim as holy convocations; they are my appointed feasts.'
verses.comment: 'Appointed feasts' translates 'moed', indicating set times established by God.

verses.text: Six days shall work be done, but on the seventh day is a Sabbath of complete rest, a holy convocation. You shall do no work. It is a Sabbath to the Lord in all your dwellings.
verses.comment: 'Sabbath of complete rest' translates a strong term for rest; 'holy convocation' refers to a sacred assembly.

verses.text: These are the appointed feasts of the Lord, the holy convocations, which you shall proclaim at their appointed times.
verses.comment: Repetition of the idea: these festivals are at God’s set times.

verses.text: In the first month, on the fourteenth day of the month at twilight, is the Lord’s Passover.
verses.comment: ‘At twilight’ literally means 'between the evenings,' the start of the 14th day.

verses.text: On the fifteenth day of the same month is the Feast of Unleavened Bread to the Lord; for seven days you shall eat unleavened bread.
verses.comment: Unleavened Bread follows Passover, starting on 15th Nisan.

verses.text: On the first day you shall have a holy convocation; you shall do no ordinary work.
verses.comment: ‘Ordinary work’ means vocational work; certain tasks were still permitted.

verses.text: But you shall offer a food offering to the Lord for seven days. On the seventh day is a holy convocation; you shall do no ordinary work.
verses.comment: Concludes the Unleavened Bread with another day of rest and gathering.

verses.text: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: Another introductory formula for revelation.

verses.text: Speak to the people of Israel and say to them, 'When you come into the land that I give you and reap its harvest, you shall bring the sheaf of the firstfruits of your harvest to the priest,
verses.comment: 'Sheaf' is 'omer', the first portion of the barley harvest.

verses.text: and he shall wave the sheaf before the Lord, so that you may be accepted. On the day after the Sabbath the priest shall wave it.
verses.comment: 'Wave' means to present before the Lord.

verses.text: And on the day when you wave the sheaf, you shall offer a male lamb a year old without blemish as a burnt offering to the Lord.
verses.comment: A regular burnt offering accompanies the sheaf.

verses.text: And the grain offering with it shall be two tenths of an ephah of fine flour mixed with oil, a food offering to the Lord with a pleasing aroma, and its drink offering shall be of wine, a fourth of a hin.
verses.comment: Details the offerings prescribed for firstfruits.

verses.text: And you shall eat neither bread nor roasted grain nor new grain until this same day, until you have brought the offering of your God. It is a statute forever throughout your generations in all your dwellings.
verses.comment: No new grain may be eaten until the offering is made.

verses.text: And you shall count for yourselves from the day after the Sabbath, from the day that you brought the sheaf of the wave offering, seven full weeks shall be counted.
verses.comment: Counting begins after the Sabbath following Passover, for the festival of Weeks.

verses.text: You shall count fifty days to the day after the seventh Sabbath; then you shall present a new grain offering to the Lord.
verses.comment: Fifty days from Firstfruits to Pentecost (Weeks).

verses.text: You shall bring from your homes two loaves of bread to be waved, made of two tenths of an ephah of fine flour; they shall be baked with leaven, as firstfruits to the Lord.
verses.comment: Only here are loaves with leavened bread offered.

verses.text: And you shall present with the bread seven lambs a year old without blemish, one bull from the herd, and two rams. They shall be a burnt offering to the Lord, with their grain offering and their drink offerings, a food offering with a pleasing aroma to the Lord.
verses.comment: Outlines prescribed sacrifices for the festival of Weeks.

verses.text: And you shall offer one male goat for a sin offering, and two male lambs a year old as a sacrifice of peace offerings.
verses.comment: Sin and peace offerings complete the festival's sacrifices.

verses.text: And the priest shall wave them with the bread of the firstfruits as a wave offering before the Lord, with the two lambs. They shall be holy to the Lord for the priest.
verses.comment: The bread and lambs were for the priest.

verses.text: And you shall make a proclamation on this same day; you shall hold a holy convocation. You shall do no ordinary work. It is a statute forever in all your dwellings throughout your generations.
verses.comment: A day of rest and sacred assembly is commanded.

verses.text: And when you reap the harvest of your land, you shall not reap your field right up to its edge, nor shall you gather the gleanings of your harvest. You shall leave them for the poor and for the sojourner. I am the Lord your God.
verses.comment: Reminds Israel to show mercy to the poor and foreigners.

verses.text: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: Another introduction to a new festival section.

verses.text: Speak to the people of Israel, saying, In the seventh month, on the first day of the month, you shall have a day of solemn rest, a memorial proclaimed with trumpet blasts, a holy convocation.
verses.comment: This is the Feast of Trumpets (later Rosh Hashanah).

verses.text: You shall do no ordinary work, and you shall offer a food offering to the Lord.
verses.comment: Work is forbidden; an offering is required.

verses.text: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: Introduction to the Day of Atonement laws.

verses.text: Now on the tenth day of this seventh month is the Day of Atonement. It shall be for you a holy convocation, and you shall afflict yourselves and offer a food offering to the Lord.
verses.comment: 'Afflict yourselves' refers to fasting or self-denial.

verses.text: And you shall do no work on this same day, for it is the Day of Atonement, to make atonement for you before the Lord your God.
verses.comment: Complete abstention from labor is commanded.

verses.text: For whoever is not afflicted on this same day shall be cut off from his people.
verses.comment: 'Cut off' likely means excommunication or severe penalty.

verses.text: And whoever does any work on this same day, that person I will destroy from among his people.
verses.comment: Very strong warning about working on the Day of Atonement.

verses.text: You shall do no work at all. It is a statute forever throughout your generations in all your dwellings.
verses.comment: Reiteration of the absolute rest required.

verses.text: It shall be to you a Sabbath of solemn rest, and you shall afflict yourselves. On the ninth day of the month, from evening to evening, you shall keep your Sabbath.
verses.comment: 'From evening to evening' defines biblical days.

verses.text: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: Introduction to the rules for the Feast of Booths (Tabernacles).

verses.text: Speak to the people of Israel, saying, On the fifteenth day of this seventh month and for seven days is the Feast of Booths to the Lord.
verses.comment: 'Booths' or 'Tabernacles' (Sukkot in Hebrew).

verses.text: On the first day shall be a holy convocation; you shall do no ordinary work.
verses.comment: Begins with a day of rest and assembly.

verses.text: For seven days you shall present food offerings to the Lord. On the eighth day you shall hold a holy convocation and present a food offering to the Lord. It is a solemn assembly; you shall do no ordinary work.
verses.comment: Eighth day marks the festival’s conclusion (Shemini Atzeret).

verses.text: These are the appointed feasts of the Lord, which you shall proclaim as holy convocations, to present food offerings to the Lord, burnt offerings and grain offerings, sacrifices and drink offerings, each on its proper day—
verses.comment: Recap of the legal summary of all feasts.

verses.text: besides the Lord’s Sabbaths, and besides your gifts and all your vow offerings and all your freewill offerings, which you give to the Lord.
verses.comment: Feast offerings are in addition to regular sacrifices.

verses.text: On the fifteenth day of the seventh month, when you have gathered in the produce of the land, you shall keep the feast of the Lord for seven days. On the first day shall be a solemn rest, and on the eighth day shall be a solemn rest.
verses.comment: Harvest festival context connects to Tabernacles.

verses.text: And on the first day you shall take the fruit of splendid trees, branches of palm trees and boughs of leafy trees and willows of the brook, and you shall rejoice before the Lord your God for seven days.
verses.comment: These are the traditional materials for building Sukkot huts.

verses.text: You shall keep it as a feast to the Lord for seven days in the year. It is a statute forever throughout your generations; you shall keep it in the seventh month.
verses.comment: Command for permanent observance of the festival.

verses.text: You shall live in booths for seven days; all native-born in Israel shall live in booths,
verses.comment: Reiterates the dwelling in temporary shelters.

verses.text: that your generations may know that I made the people of Israel live in booths when I brought them out of the land of Egypt. I am the Lord your God.
verses.comment: Remembrance of the Exodus and wilderness period.

verses.text: Thus Moses announced the appointed feasts of the Lord to the people of Israel.
verses.comment: Summary conclusion of the chapter.
